article.headline: Auburn 58, Mississippi 50
article.story: AUBURN, Ala. (AP) -- All it took was a little halftime talking-to. After a sluggish first half that saw Auburn down by as much as 14 points, the Tigers came back following a scolding from head coach Jeff Lebo to take a 58-50 victory over Mississippi Wednesday night. "We came out lackadaisical in the first half, but coach yelled at us at halftime and got us going," said Ronny LeMelle, who scored a game-high 18 points. "We came out in the second half and played as a team and got good results." "That was not a PG-rated halftime," Lebo added. "I thought in the second half we had a lot more energy. The first half was horrendous. One thing I did tell them is they couldn't have beaten a bad JV team in the first half." Auburn (10-10, 2-7 Southeastern Conference) trailed 29-23 at the half after the Rebels (13-9, 3-6) shot 50 percent from the field and went 5-of-9 from the free throw line. Ole Miss, which has now lost six straight, had 17 field goals and 23 turnovers. "Some nights, we'll have guys that look like all-conference," Rebels head coach Rod Barnes said following the game. "It's been difficult. We are going through some growing pains. I take it personally. We need better leadership on the floor." The Rebels took a 42-33 lead on two free throws by Mike Smith with 10:12 left. Then, LeMelle scored seven points to fuel an 11-2 run to bring the Tigers back. LeMelle's 3-pointer gave Auburn the lead for good with 3:36 to play. Neither team scored again until his layup with 1:05 left. Josh Dollard and LeMelle hit two free throws apiece over the final 40 seconds for the Tigers. Dwayne Curtis, who leads the Rebels in scoring and rebounds, was held to his season low in SEC games with seven points Wednesday night. He played one season at Auburn before transferring two years ago. Quantez Robertson and Brett Howell had nine points apiece for the Tigers. Howell made 3-of-5 3-pointers in 12 minutes off the bench. Leading scorer Rasheem Barrett had just six points. Todd Abernathy led Ole Miss with 10 points and Clarence Sanders added nine. Ole Miss has won the last three meetings overall, but the Tigers have a 44-9 series edge at home.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.
